page.title: 12FAUNA
page.content: Although the land is intensively farmed, the hedgerows abound with animal life. Oak, ash, beech, field maple, crab-apple and holly grow at intervals in the hedges and in their roots squeaks and rustlings betray the homes of invisible creatures. Walks are full of surprises. You may find the nest of a fieldmouse,who will eye you suspiciously for a moment before slipping away. An inquisitive stoat will play "peek-a-boo" behind a treetrunk or a squirrel, missing his footing, may drop suddenly at your feet in a flurry of leaves, pick himself up and scamper away. Pheasants hide silently as you pass, then rise up squawking loudly behind you. On the lower ground an adder might cross your path. Wild roe deer inhabit the woods and bound away as you pass, leaping the fences effortlessly.
